The good old herdsman laid his work aside,</br>And thus complacent to the chief reply'd:

'Whate'er you ask, O stranger, I'll impart,</br>Whate'er you wish, and with a cheerful heart;</br>For much I venerate the son of May,</br>Who stands rever'd in every publick way:</br>Those most he hates, of all the gods on high,</br>Who the lone traveller's request deny.

'The numerous flocks your eyes behold around,</br>With which the vales are stor'd, the hills are crown'd,</br>Augeas owns; o'er various walks they spread,</br>In different meads, in different pastures fed;</br>Some on the banks of Elisuntus stray,</br>Some where divine Alpheus winds his way,</br>Some in Buprasium, where rich wines abound,</br>And some in this well-cultivated ground.</br>And though exceeding many flocks are told,</br>Each separate flock enjoys a separate fold.</br>Here, though of oxen numerous herds are seen,</br>Yet springs the herbage ever fresh and green</br>In the moist marsh of Menius:  every mead,</br>And vale irriguous, where the cattle feed,</br>Produce sweet herbs, embalm'd in dewy tears,</br>Whose fragrant virtue fattens well the steers.</br>Behold that stall beyond the winding flood,</br>Which to the right appears by yonder wood</br>Where the wild olive, and perennial plane</br>Grow, spread, and flourish, great Apollo's fane,</br>To which the hinds, to which the shepherds bow,</br>And deem him greatest deity below!</br>Next are the stalls of swains, whose labours bring.</br>Abundant riches to the wealthy king;</br>Four times each year the fertile soil they plow,</br>And gather thrice the harvests which they sow;</br>The lab'ring hinds, whose hands the vineyards dress,</br>Whose feet the grapes in purple autumn press,</br>Know well the vast domain Augeas owns,</br>Rich fields whose lap the golden ear imbrowns,</br>Or shaded gardens, far as yonder hills,</br>Whose brows are water'd by resplendent rills;</br>This spacious tract we tend with daily care,</br>As fits those swains who rural labours share.

But say, (and all my service you shall claim)</br>Say for what cause you here a stranger came:</br>Would you the king or his attendants see?</br>I can conduct you; only trust to me.</br>For such your form, and such your manly grace,</br>You seem deriv'd from no ignoble race:</br>Sure thus the gods, that boast celestial birth,</br>Appear majestic to the sons of earth.'

He spoke, and thus Jove's valiant son reply'd;</br>"My wandering steps let some kind shepherd guide</br>"To king Augeas, whom these realms obey;</br>To see Augeas am I come this way.</br>But if fair justice the good monarch draws</br>To Elis, to administer the laws;</br>Conduct me to some honourable swain,</br>Who here presides among his rural train,</br>That I to him my purpose may disclose,</br>And follow what his prudence shall propose:</br>For heaven's eternal wisdom has decreed,</br>That man of man should ever stand in need."

Thus he; the good old herdsman thus reply'd:</br>'Sure some immortal being is your guide:</br>For lo!  your business is already done;</br>Last night the king, descendant of the sun,</br>With royal Phyleus, from the town withdrew,</br>His flocks unnumber'd, and his herds to view.</br>Thus when great kings their own concerns explore,</br>By wise attention they augment their store.</br>But let me quick, for time is on the wing,</br>In yonder tent conduct you to the king.'

This said, he walk'd before his royal guest,</br>Much wondering, much revolving in his breast,</br>When at his back the lion's spoils he saw,</br>And in his hand the club infusing awe.</br>He wish'd to ask the hero, whence he sprung?</br>The rising query dy'd upon his tongue:</br>He fear'd the freedom might be deem'd a fault:</br>'Tis difficult to know another's thought.

The watchful dogs, as near the stalls they went,</br>Perceiv'd their coming by their tread and scent,</br>With open mouths from every part they run,</br>And bay'd incessant great Amphitryon's son;</br>But round the swain they wagg'd their tales and play'd,</br>And gently whining secret joy betray'd.</br>Loose on the ground the stones that ready lay</br>Eager he snatch'd, and drove the dogs away;</br>With his rough voice he terrified them all,</br>Though pleas'd to find them guardians of his stall.</br>'Ye gods!  (the good old herdsman thus began)</br>What useful animals are dogs to man?</br>Had heav'n but sent intelligence to know</br>On whom to rage, the friendly or the foe,</br>No creature then could challenge honour more,</br>But now too furious, and too fierce they roar.'

He spoke; the growling mastives ceas'd to bay,</br>And stole obsequious to their stalls away.</br>The sun now westward drove his radiant steeds,</br>And evening mild the noontide heat succeeds;</br>His orb declining from the pastures calls</br>Sheep to their folds, and oxen to their stalls.</br>Herd following herd, it joy'd the chief to see</br>Unnumber'd cattle winding o'er the lea.</br>Like watery clouds arising thick in heaven,</br>By the rough South, or Thracian Boreas driven;</br>So fast the shadowy vapours mount on high,</br>They cover all the region of the sky;</br>Still more and more the gathering tempest brings,</br>And weightier burdens on its weary wings.</br>Thus thickening march the cattle o'er the plain,</br>More than the roads or meadows can contain,</br>The lusty herds incessant bellowing keep,</br>The stalls are fill'd with steers, the folds with sheep.</br>Though numerous slaves stand round of every kind,</br>All have their several offices assign'd.</br>Some tie the cow's hind legs, to make her stand</br>Still, and obedient to the milker's hand:</br>Some give to tender calves the swelling teat,</br>Their sides distend with milky beverage sweet.</br>Some form fat cheeses with the housewife's art,</br>Some drive the heifers from the bulls apart.</br>Augeas visited the stalls around,</br>To see what stores in herds and flocks abound;</br>With curious eye he mov'd majestic on,</br>Join'd by Alcides and his royal son.</br>Here Hercules, of great and steady soul,</br>Whom mean amazement never could controll,</br>Admir'd such droves in myriads to behold,</br>Such spreading flocks, that never could be told,</br>Not one king's wealth he thought them, nor of ten,</br>Though greatest of the rulers over men:</br>The Sun his sire this privilege assign'd,</br>To be in flocks and herds more rich than all mankind:</br>These still increas'd; no plague e'er render'd vain</br>The gainful labour of the shepherd-swain;</br>Year following year his industry was blest,</br>More calves were rear'd, and still the last were best.</br>No cows e'er cast their young, or e'er declin'd,</br>The calves were chiefly of the female kind.</br>With these three hundred bulls, a comely sight,</br>Whose horns were crooked, and whose legs were white;</br>And twice an hundred of bright glossy red,</br>By whom the business of increase was sped:</br>But twelve, the flower of all, exulting run</br>In the green pastures, sacred to the sun;</br>The stately swan was not so silver white,</br>And in the meads they took ineffable delight:</br>These, when gaunt lions from the mountain's brow</br>Descend terrific on the herds below,</br>Rush to the war, the savage foe they gore,</br>Their eyes look death, and horribly they roar.</br>But most majestic these bold bulls among</br>Stalk'd Phaeton, the sturdy and the strong;</br>So radiant, so refulgent from afar,</br>The shepherd-swains compar'd him to a star.</br>When round the shoulders of the chief he spy'd,</br>Alarming sight!  the lion's tawny hide,</br>Full at his flank he aim'd his iron head,</br>And proudly doom'd the matchless hero dead:</br>But watchful Hercules, devoid of fear,</br>Seiz'd his left horn, and stopp'd his mad career;</br>Prone to the earth his stubborn neck he prest,</br>Then writh'd him round, and bruis'd his ample chest,</br>At one bold push exerted all his strength,</br>And high in air upheld him at arm's length.</br>Through all the wondering train amazement ran,</br>Silent they gaz'd, and thought him more than man.

Phyleus and Hercules (the day far spent)</br>Left the rich pastures, and to Elis went;</br>The footpath first, which tow'rd the city lay,</br>Led from the stalls, but narrow was the way;</br>Through vineyards next it past, and gloomy glades,</br>Hard to distinguish in the greenwood shades.</br>The devious way as noble Phyleus led,</br>To his right shoulder he inclined his head,</br>And slowly marching through the verdant grove,</br>Thus mild bespoke the progeny of Jove:

'By your last bold achievement it appears,</br>Great chief, your fame long since has reach'd my ears.</br>For here arriv'd a youthful Argive swain,</br>From Helice that borders on the main,</br>Who for a truth among th' Epeans told,</br>That late he saw a Grecian, brave and bold,</br>Slay a fell lion, fell to husbandmen,</br>That in the Nemean forest made his den:</br>Whether the chief from sacred Argos came,</br>Or proud Mycene, or Tirynthe claim</br>His birth, I heard not; yet he trac'd his line,</br>If true my tale, from Perseus the divine.</br>No Greek but you could such a toil sustain;</br>I reason from that mighty monster slain,</br>A perilous encounter!  whose rough hide</br>Protects your shoulders, and adorns your side.</br>Say then, if you are he, the Grecian bold,</br>Of whom the Argive's wonderous tale was told:</br>Say, what dread weapon drank the monster's blood,</br>And how he wander'd to the Nemean wood.</br>For not in Greece such savages are found,</br>No beasts thus huge infest Achaian ground;</br>She breeds the ravenous wolf, the bear, the boar,</br>Pernicious monsters!  but she breeds no more.</br>Some wonder'd at accounts so strange and new,</br>Thought the Greek boastful, and his tale untrue.'</br>Thus Phyleus spoke, and as the path grew wide,</br>He walk'd attentive by the hero's side,</br>To hear distinct the toil-sustaining man,</br>Who thus, obsequious to the prince, began:

"Son of Augeas, what of me you heard</br>Is strictly true, nor has the stranger err'd.</br>But since you wish to know, my tongue shall tell,</br>From whence the monster came, and how he fell:</br>Though many Greeks have mention'd this affair,</br>None can the truth with certainty declare.</br>Tis thought some god, by vengeful anger sway'd,</br>Sent this sore plague for sacrifice unpaid,</br>To punish the Phoroneans; like a flood</br>He delug'd the Pisaean fields with blood:</br>The Bembinaeans, miserable men,</br>Felt his chief rage, the neighbours to his den.</br>The hardy task, this hideous beast to kill,</br>Eurystheus first enjoin'd me to fulfill,</br>But hop'd me slain:  on the bold conflict bent,</br>Arm'd to the field with bow and darts I went:</br>A solid club, of rude wild olive made,</br>Rough in its rugged rind my right hand sway'd:</br>On Helicon's fair hill the tree I found,</br>And with the roots I wrench'd it from the ground.</br>When the close covert I approach'd, where lay</br>The lordly lion lurking for his prey,</br>I bent my bow, firm fix'd the string, and strait</br>Notch'd on the nerve the messenger of fate:</br>Then circumspect I pry'd with curious eye,</br>First, unobserv'd, the ravenous beast to spy.</br>Now mid-day reign'd; I neither could explore</br>His paw's broad print, nor hear his hideous roar;</br>Nor labouring rustic find, nor shepherd-swain,</br>Nor cowherd tending cattle on the plain,</br>To point the lion's lair:  fear chill'd them all,</br>And kept the herds and herdsmen in the stall.</br>I search'd the groves and saw my foe at length;</br>Then was the moment to exert my strength.</br>Long ere dim evening clos'd, he sought his den,</br>Gorg'd with the flesh of cattle and of men:</br>With slaughter stain'd his squalid mane appear'd,</br>Stern was his face, his chest with blood besmear'd,</br>And with his pliant tongue he lick'd his gory beard.</br>Mid shady shrubs I hid myself with care,</br>Expecting he might issue from his lair.</br>Full at his flank I sent a shaft, in vain,</br>The harmless shaft rebounded on the plain.</br>Stunn'd at the shock, from earth the savage rais'd</br>His tawny head, and all around him gaz'd;</br>Wondering from whence the feather'd vengeance flew,</br>He gnash'd his horrid teeth, tremendous to the view.</br>Vex'd that the first had unavailing fled,</br>A second arrow from the nerve I sped:</br>In his broad chest, the mansion of his heart,</br>I lanch'd the shaft with ineffectual art;</br>His hair, his hide the feather'd death repell;</br>Before his feet it innocently fell.</br>Enrag'd, once more, I try'd my bow to draw,</br>Then first his foe the furious monster saw:</br>He lash'd his sturdy sides with stern delight,</br>And rising in his rage prepar'd for fight.</br>With instant ire his mane erected grew,</br>His hair look'd horrid, of a brindled hue;</br>Circling his back, he seem'd in act to bound,</br>And like a bow he bent his body round:</br>As when the fig-tree skilful wheelers take,</br>For rolling chariots rapid wheels to make;</br>The fellies first, in fires that gently glow,</br>Gradual they heat, and like a circle bow;</br>Awhile in curves the pliant timber stands,</br>Then springs at once elastic from their hands.</br>On me thus from afar, his foe to wound,</br>Sprung the fell lion with impetuous bound.</br>My left hand held my darts direct before,</br>Around my breast a thick strong garb I wore;</br>My right, club-guarded, dealt a deadly blow</br>Full on the temples of the rushing foe:</br>So hard his skull, that with the sturdy stroke,</br>My knotted club of rough wild-olive broke:</br>Yet ere I clos'd, his savage fury fled,</br>With trembling legs he stood, and nodding head;</br>The forceful onset had contus'd his brain,</br>Dim mists obscur'd his eyes, and agonizing pain.</br>This I perceiv'd; and now, an easy prey,</br>I threw my arrows and my bow away,</br>And ere the beast recover'd of his wound,</br>Seiz'd his thick neck, and pinn'd him to the ground;</br>With all my might on his broad back I prest,</br>Lest his fell claws should tear my adverse breast;</br>Then mounting, close my legs in his I twin'd,</br>And with my feet secur'd his paws behind;</br>My thighs I guarded, and with all my strength</br>Heav'd him from earth, and held him at arm's length,</br>And strangled thus the fellest of the fell;</br>His mighty soul descending sunk to hell.</br>The conquest gain'd, fresh doubts my mind divide,</br>How shall I strip the monster's shaggy hide?</br>Hard task!  for the tough skin repell'd the dint</br>Of pointed wood, keen steel, or sharpest flint:</br>Some god inspir'd me, standing still in pause,</br>To flay the lion with the lion's claws.</br>This I accomplish'd, and the spoil now yields</br>A firm security in fighting fields:</br>Thus, Phyleus, was the Nemean monster slain,</br>The terror of the forest and the plain,</br>That flocks and herds devour'd, and many a village swain."</br>
